question.name: 19.3.6.2 Exercise 1
question.questiontext:
Exercise

Find the general solution of the following equations.

  1. \(\displaystyle {@deq1@}\)

    \({@v1[1]@} = A\ \) [[input:ans11]] [[validation:ans11]] \(\ +\ B\ \) [[input:ans12]] [[validation:ans12]] \(\ +\ \) [[input:ans1pi]] [[validation:ans1pi]] [[feedback:prt1]]

  2. \(\displaystyle {@deq2@}\)

    \({@v2[1]@} = A\ \) [[input:ans21]] [[validation:ans21]] \(\ +\ B\ \) [[input:ans22]] [[validation:ans22]] \(\ +\ \) [[input:ans2pi]] [[validation:ans2pi]] [[feedback:prt2]]

  3. \(\displaystyle {@deq3@}\)

    Make sure to factor out the \(e^{\alpha x}\) term.

    \({@v3[1]@} =\ \) [[input:ans33]] [[validation:ans33]] \(\ \times\ \bigg(A\ \) [[input:ans31]] [[validation:ans31]] \(\ +\ B\ \) [[input:ans32]] [[validation:ans32]] \(\ \bigg)\ +\ \) [[input:ans3pi]] [[validation:ans3pi]] [[feedback:prt3]]

  4. \(\displaystyle {@deq4@}\)

    \({@v4[1]@} = A\ \) [[input:ans41]] [[validation:ans41]] \(\ +\ B\ \) [[input:ans42]] [[validation:ans42]] \(\ +\ \) [[input:ans4pi]] [[validation:ans4pi]] [[feedback:prt4]]

  5. \(\displaystyle {@deq5@}\)

    \({@v5[1]@} = A\ \) [[input:ans51]] [[validation:ans51]] \(\ +\ B\ \) [[input:ans52]] [[validation:ans52]] \(\ +\ \) [[input:ans5pi]] [[validation:ans5pi]] [[feedback:prt5]]
question.generalfeedback:
1. We are asked to find the general solution of the second order, constant coefficients, inhomogeneous differental equation

    \[{@deq1@}.\]

    First, we find the complementary function. Suppose \({@v1[1]@} = e^{k{@v1[2]@}}\) is a solution to the corresponding homogeneous equation. This gives the auxiliary equation \({@auxeq1@}\), which has roots \(k = {@a11@}\) and \(k = {@a12@}\). The complementary function therefore has the form

    \[{@v1[1]@}_\text{cp}({@v1[2]@}) = {@cf1@}.\]

    Next, we find a particular integral. Since the function on the right-hand side of the equation is a constant, we try \({@v1[1]@}_\text{p}({@v1[2]@}) = \alpha\). Its derivatives are zero, so we get the equation:

    \[{@c1@}\alpha = {@f1@},\]

    which gives \(\alpha = {@alpha1@}\).

    Therefore, the general solution is

    \[{@v1[1]@}({@v1[2]@}) = {@ta1@}.\]

  2. We are asked to find the general solution of the second order, constant coefficients, inhomogeneous differental equation

    \[{@deq2@}.\]

    First, we find the complementary function. Suppose \({@v2[1]@} = e^{k{@v2[2]@}}\) is a solution to the corresponding homogeneous equation. This gives the auxiliary equation \({@auxeq2@}\), which has roots \(k = {@a21@}\) and \(k = {@a22@}\). The complementary function therefore has the form

    \[{@v2[1]@}_\text{cp}({@v2[2]@}) = {@cf2@}.\]

    Next, we find a particular integral. Since the function on the right-hand side of the equation is a linear term, we try \({@v2[1]@}_\text{p}({@v2[2]@}) = {@pitest2@}\). Its derivatives are:

    \[\begin{aligned} \frac{\mathrm{d}{@v2[1]@}}{\mathrm{d}{@v2[2]@}} &= {@dpitest2@} \\ \frac{\mathrm{d}^2{@v2[1]@}}{\mathrm{d}{@v2[2]@}^2} &= {@ddpitest2@} \end{aligned}\]

    We substitute these in the inhomogeneous differential equation to get:

    \[{@pieq2@},\]

    which gives \(a = {@aa2@}\) and \(b = {@bb2@}\).

    Therefore, the general solution is

    \[{@v2[1]@}({@v2[2]@}) = {@ta2@}.\]

  3. We are asked to find the general solution of the second order, constant coefficients, inhomogeneous differental equation

    \[{@deq3@}.\]

    First, we find the complementary function. Suppose \({@v3[1]@} = e^{k{@v3[2]@}}\) is a solution to the corresponding homogeneous equation. This gives the auxiliary equation \({@auxeq3@}\), which has roots \(k = {@a31@}\) and \(k = {@a32@}\). The complementary function therefore has the form

    \[{@v3[1]@}_\text{cp}({@v3[2]@}) = {@cf3@}.\]

    Next, we find a particular integral. Since the function on the right-hand side of the equation is a basic trigonometric function, we try \({@v3[1]@}_\text{p}({@v3[2]@}) = {@pitest3@}\). Its derivatives are:

    \[\begin{aligned} \frac{\mathrm{d}{@v3[1]@}}{\mathrm{d}{@v3[2]@}} &= {@dpitest3@} \\ \frac{\mathrm{d}^2{@v3[1]@}}{\mathrm{d}{@v3[2]@}^2} &= {@ddpitest3@} \end{aligned}\]

    We substitute these in the inhomogeneous differential equation to get:

    \[{@pieq3@},\]

    which, equating coefficients, gives the simultaneous equations

    \[\begin{cases} {@lhs(pieq31)@} &= {@rhs(pieq31)@} \\ {@lhs(pieq32)@} &= {@rhs(pieq32)@} \end{cases}\]

    Solving these gives \(a = {@aa3@}\) and \(b = {@bb3@}\).

    Therefore, the general solution is

    \[{@v3[1]@}({@v3[2]@}) = {@ta3@}.\]

  4. We are asked to find the general solution of the second order, constant coefficients, inhomogeneous differental equation

    \[{@deq4@}.\]

    First, we find the complementary function. Suppose \({@v4[1]@} = e^{k{@v4[2]@}}\) is a solution to the corresponding homogeneous equation. This gives the auxiliary equation \({@auxeq4@}\), which has roots \(k = {@a41@}\) and \(k = {@a42@}\). The complementary function therefore has the form

    \[{@v4[1]@}_\text{cp}({@v4[2]@}) = {@cf4@}.\]

    Next, we find a particular integral. Since the function on the right-hand side of the equation is a exponential, we try \({@v4[1]@}_\text{p}({@v4[2]@}) = {@pitest4@}\). Its derivatives are:

    \[\begin{aligned} \frac{\mathrm{d}{@v4[1]@}}{\mathrm{d}{@v4[2]@}} &= {@dpitest4@} \\ \frac{\mathrm{d}^2{@v4[1]@}}{\mathrm{d}{@v4[2]@}^2} &= {@ddpitest4@} \end{aligned}\]

    We substitute these in the inhomogeneous differential equation to get:

    \[{@pieq4@},\]

    which, equating coefficients, gives the equation:

    \[{@pieq41@}\]

    Solving this gives \(a = {@aa4@}\).

    Therefore, the general solution is

    \[{@v4[1]@}({@v4[2]@}) = {@ta4@}.\]

  5. We are asked to find the general solution of the second order, constant coefficients, inhomogeneous differental equation

    \[{@deq5@}.\]

    First, we find the complementary function. Suppose \({@v5[1]@} = e^{k{@v5[2]@}}\) is a solution to the corresponding homogeneous equation. This gives the auxiliary equation \({@auxeq5@}\), which has roots \(k = {@a51@}\) and \(k = {@a52@}\). The complementary function therefore has the form

    \[{@v5[1]@}_\text{cp}({@v5[2]@}) = {@cf5@}.\]

    Next, we find a particular integral. Since the function on the right-hand side of the equation is a exponential, we try \({@v5[1]@}_\text{p}({@v5[2]@}) = {@pitest5@}\). Its derivatives are:

    \[\begin{aligned} \frac{\mathrm{d}{@v5[1]@}}{\mathrm{d}{@v5[2]@}} &= {@dpitest5@} \\ \frac{\mathrm{d}^2{@v5[1]@}}{\mathrm{d}{@v5[2]@}^2} &= {@ddpitest5@} \end{aligned}\]

    We substitute these in the inhomogeneous differential equation to get:

    \[{@pieq5@},\]

    which, equating coefficients, gives the equation:

    \[{@pieq51@}\]

    Solving this gives \(a = {@aa5@}\).

    Therefore, the general solution is

    \[{@v5[1]@}({@v5[2]@}) = {@ta5@}.\]

stackoptions.prtcorrect: Correct answer, well done.
stackoptions.prtpartiallycorrect: Your answer is partially correct.
stackoptions.prtincorrect: Incorrect answer.

stackprtnode.falsefeedback: Your complementary function is not fully correct.
